text:
As I'm participating more I should probably do this...

I've been programming since the 1970s. Originally focused on physics and mathematics, I was lured astray by certain findings in theoretical computer science. This is my 35th year as a Lisper and Emacs user. My first purely functional programming language was <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Miranda_(programming_language)|Miranda>, c. 1987.

My desert island programming languages are Scheme, FORTH, Smalltalk and ML (Prolog's features are better as a library), but my most used language since 2009 is Clojure.

While I _prefer_ to use highly interactive languages, I've also written millions of lines of C code in the course of my career, which has included all sorts of things from building operating systems, clustered filesystems and high-performance language runtimes to creating the first purpose-built <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Triplestore|Triplestore> for the semantic web to building some of the earliest streaming databases and complex event processing systems to building a big document understanding system using a mix of modern statistical and classical <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Symbolic_artificial_intelligence|GOFAI> techniques (most recent startup exit).

<@UC2A2ARPT> interviewed me for the podcast last summer:

<https://futureofcoding.org/episodes/041.html>

At university I also studied classical music composition and played guitar in the jazz orchestra. Some years later, while doing a startup in the Valley, I attended art school at night. If you're interested in some recent work at the intersection of art + tech, here's a talk I gave last autumn in Helsinki:

<https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TeXCvh5X5w0>

Looking forward to getting to know everyone. :slightly_smiling_face:
